Legal_Issue: Timeliness of complaint and extension of time limit under human rights legislation
Evidence_Assessment: Complaint filed in December 2001 regarding an alleged act in February 1999
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to justify late filing or need for extension
Legal_Rule: Subsection 41(1)(e) of the Canadian Human Rights Act requires complaints to be filed within one year unless extended
Procedural_Issue: Whether the Commission properly applied the time limit and ensured procedural fairness
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged gender discrimination by employer (Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation)
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; complaint dismissed on procedural grounds
Key_Evidence_Considered: Date of alleged discrimination (February 1999) and date of complaint (December 2001)
Legal_Framework: Administrative law and human rights law
Applicant_Challenge: Commission erred in dismissing complaint due to time limit
Standard_of_Proof: Balance of probabilities, as applicable in administrative proceedings
Defendant_Response: Complaint was out of time and no justification for extension
Outcome: Application dismissed, costs awarded to respondent
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Failure to file within statutory time limit
Applicable_Process: Human rights complaint process followed by judicial review
